title: How Lil Nas X Inspired a New Cowboy-Hat Craze
text:
Two weeks ago, I failed to buy a cowboy hat. I was visiting Santa Fe, N.M., a town filled with artsy retirees, armadillo-hide cowboy boots, and yes, traditional Western toppers. For days, at specialty stores and vintage emporiums, I plopped on every hat I could find. The most compelling was a cream-colored number I spied at a western-wear shop on the south side of town—a large hat with a grin-shaped brim and a lovely tobacco-colored band ringing its crown. On the shelf it looked promising but when I tried it on, I had to grapple with the fact that a bulbous cowboy-hat-shaped cheesecake had somehow landed on my head. I asked the only other customer in the store, a leathery gent in pointy boots and ripped jeans, for a second opinion. “I like it,” he drawled approvingly. Whatever he saw, I didn’t. Sheepishly, I left the store, and Santa Fe, hatless.

Why was I craving a cowboy hat to begin with? Good old-fashioned jumping-on-the-bandwagon. While the style’s comeback is still in its fledgling stages, cowboy hats are being recontextualized, adopted by young urban men who’ve never inhaled the whiff of cow-pie. The hats are “becoming more of a normal thing for people to wear,” said Tom Borges, 25, a photographer in Madison, Wis., who owns seven, including one custom-made by Los Angeles milliner Alexander Westwood.

Ronald Reagan in 1980. Photo: Getty Images

One particularly potent evangelist for the style is Lil Nas X. You rarely see the charming country-rapper behind the megahit “Old Town Road” without a honking western hat on his head, from the red carpet to concert stages. Lil Nas X’s viral success coincides with the “Yee-haw agenda,” an internet phenomenon of young, mostly black, men and women celebrating cowboy culture. Other conspicuous advocates of the hat: Denver Broncos linebacker Von Miller, New Jersey Devils defenseman P.K. Subban, actors Walton Goggins and Matthew McConaughey have been seen in Western hats. (True to form, country stars like Garth Brooks, Chris Stapleton and Tim McGraw remain faithful to the style as well.)

“ ‘One potent evangelist for the cowboy hat’s revival is Lil Nas X.’ ”

Aida O’Toole, the owner of J.J. Hat Center in Midtown Manhattan, an area rarely traversed by Appaloosas, said she’s recorded an uptick in the number of Western lids sold over the past couple of years. She likened this moment to 1980 when the release of the John Travolta vehicle “Urban Cowboy” inspired city-bound copycats. She credits men under 40 as the demographic most responsible for spurring the new craze-in-the-making.

Prince William in 2011. Photo: Getty Images

That generation was raised by fathers who generally went to work hatless, rebelling against their own fedora-clad dads of the “Mad Men” era. Today, some young men, unburdened by that baggage, see cowboy hats as a joyous fashion statement. Ms. O’Toole noted that her customers are “not afraid to wear color” or spend on ten-gallon caps ostentatiously banded with beads or dangling with add-ons.

Even when not topped by some turquoise trinket, a cowboy hat “is something to talk about,” said Ricky Bolin, the general manager of Hat-Co, which is a licensed manufacturer of Stetson. Though John B. Stetson created the cowboy hat in 1865 as a way to “protect him from the elements,” Mr. Bolin is well aware that many young men today buy the hats for looks alone. And in considerable numbers: He says that Hat-Co is currently on track to log its best sales year ever.

Willie Nelson in 2018. Photo: Getty Images

And what of my Santa Fe failure? Ms. O’Toole counseled me that I may have just been trying on the wrong hats: “It’s not like everyone is wearing the old J.R. hat,” she said, referencing the Texas-size swoop-brimmer that J.R. Ewing wore on “Dallas” in the 1980s. A colossal see-it-from-across-the-plains cowboy hat might work in New Mexico, where giant silver belt buckles are practically conformist. But back on the east coast, in that hat, I’d look like a “Gunsmoke” goober who got lost on the way back to the homestead.

I can see why subtler, smaller-brimmed westerns, like Stetson’s “Open Road” model, are selling briskly. I recently tried one on in Manhattan: Unlike the satellite dish of a hat I’d encountered in Santa Fe, it suited my five-foot-ten stature. It was a compact horizontal halo circling my head, blending Marlboro Man machismo with “I still have to ride the subway in this thing” modesty. Clearly I just had to leave the West to find the Western hat of my dreams.

description: The country rapper is just one of the urban millennials who’ve jumped on this unlikely Western bandwagon. Our men’s fashion editor attempts to join them.
